update.description:
A plugin that can be configured in the world file to:emit events when:
* the simulation is paused/resumed
* a model enters/leaves a region in space
* a model is created/destroyed

the events are published with SimEvent proto on the "/gazebo/sim_events" topic.

This is a subset of the Mentor2 scoring utilities. More events (going through a gate, falling) will be added in the future.

The test/integration/sim_events.cc uses the test/world/sim_events.world where the SimEvents are specified.
update.title: SimEvents

content.raw:
In this failing test, I move models (beer cans) using a "set pose" method, and detect motion in and out of a region during the plugin update.
A better test would be to apply a force to the model to make it move (rather than teleporting it). I expect this could be easier on the physics engines.
I'm not sure its the real issue here, and if it is worth modifying the test. Any thoughts, anyone?
content.html: In this failing test, I move models (beer cans) using a "set pose" method, and detect motion in and out of a region during the plugin update. A better test would be to apply a force to the model to make it move (rather than teleporting it). I expect this could be easier on the physics engines. I'm not sure its the real issue here, and if it is worth modifying the test. Any thoughts, anyone?

content.raw: I won't try to deny that I use i++ in general, I think that in this particular case your suggestion has no advantage (not even [performance](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24886/is-there-a-performance-difference-between-i-and-i-in-c) , i not being used in the loop).
content.html: I won't try to deny that I use i++ in general, I think that in this particular case your suggestion has no advantage (not even performance , i not being used in the loop).

~~~

content.raw:
The active is (another) feature that got reduced in scope (events should eventually be chain-able together), but the `active` flag ended up being always true. However, since you noticed it was odd, I implemented a read from world file feature as so: 
* `active` remains true in the ctor (not letting the compiler play dice on it) 
* the Load method now actively looks for an "active" (optional) element where `active` can be overridden.
content.html: The active is (another) feature that got reduced in scope (events should eventually be chain-able together), but the active flag ended up being always true. However, since you noticed it was odd, I implemented a read from world file feature as so: active remains true in the ctor (not letting the compiler play dice on it) the Load method now actively looks for an "active" (optional) element where active can be overridden.

content.raw: I understand that its a good practice to use your own exception hierarchy in a project, so that you can "catch" them specifically. I prefer it that way, and that is why I often start with a type like this. Let's start a conversation about how we can better use exceptions in Gazebo.
content.html: I understand that its a good practice to use your own exception hierarchy in a project, so that you can "catch" them specifically. I prefer it that way, and that is why I often start with a type like this. Let's start a conversation about how we can better use exceptions in Gazebo.

content.raw:
Comment updated.
That was the original plan. However the new plan is to use collision detectors (not yet available to all physics engines), so I cut out the unfinished Volume type hierarchy as we will most likely not use the volume class any more.
content.html: Comment updated. That was the original plan. However the new plan is to use collision detectors (not yet available to all physics engines), so I cut out the unfinished Volume type hierarchy as we will most likely not use the volume class any more.
